reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s decision-theoretic/moral-theoretic “filter” (completeness + VNM axioms → cardinal v with thresholds like v>0.5), and argues that this makes the headline conclusion (“most plausible views are fussy / easygoingness unlikely”) overgeneral, at best conditional on VNM-style comparability. This is fairly central because the essay explicitly uses that framework to define and compare ‘mostly-great’ across futures and to motivate high-stakes comparisons (e.g., eutopia/extinction gambles vs guaranteed great futures). However, the position also offers non-VNM-dependent motivations for fragility/narrow targeting (many single-point moral failures; multiplicative-factor toy model; structural claims about scaling/aggregation) and even flags that some moral views may violate completeness, so the critique doesn’t collapse the whole case. The objection plausibly weakens the scope/ambition of the conclusion and would force either a defense of the VNM restriction or a parallel argument under alternative formalisms, but it doesn’t show that non-VNM views are actually easygoing or that the narrow-target result disappears. Mostly correct, though it somewhat overstates that VNM ‘pre-decides’ tiny-probability dominance (which depends more on utility shape/unboundedness than VNM per se). Clear, focused, and low on fluff.
title: VNM axioms bake in fussiness by excluding incomparability and constraint-based views
